APPENDIX B
MEMORANDUM ON PUBLIC DISCUSSION AREA - NATIONAL ADULT EDUCATION PROJECT
By William Harley
April k9 1952
The following summarizes conversations which the Program Coordinator held
recently with ProfessorsRobert Merton, Columbia, and Harold Lasswell, Yale*
Mr. Merton expressed interest in the talk-back proposal and felt that it
had considerable merit providing that the objectives of the program were somewhat
altered. He felt that it would not provide a valid representation of cross-
section opinion across th& country (since it would be impossible to validate
small groups of individuals as representative of regions), but that the program
could perform a significant educational function as a demonstration of the com¬
munications process. He suggested that the final ten minutes of the program be
devoted to an analysis by an expert on the preceding discussion, pointing out
instances of agreement, unresolved arguments, misunderstandings, etc., together
with the probable reasons therefor.
He felt that the "cricket vote" technique would not be a valid sampling
of public opinion, either; although he thought it might have some validity if it
were used to indicate a shift of sentiment between a pre-broadcast vote and a
vote taken during a program.
Mr. Merton agreed to serve as a consultant on a small pilot project in
this area if we could assure him that he would not be "involved in hours of fruit¬
less discussion, but could have relatively short sessions in which we reported
our activities and he gave us three or four ideas which we then went out and
acted upon."
It is proposed that we try an experimental project on the talk-back idea
with the production centered at Boston in charge of Ralph Tangney, a skilled tape
editor and writer, and with Parker Wheatley informally overseeing the operation.
Mr. Lasswell in a brief luncheon conversation March 30 gave these reactions
to proposals in the public discussion area. Lasswell said:
1. The international discussion series of the BBC, etc., has many
excellent and obvious ideas, but is a pretty conventional formula*
2. The talk-back proposal has the advantage of station participation,
and he concurs with Merton’s notion of its objective, with the addi¬
tional element that the analyst should emphasize the degree of
clarification achieved.
3. The Milton Mayer series and the talks on communications he said were
"self-evidently good ideas."
Regarding his future relations with the NAEB, Lasswell said that he was,
of course, principally interested in causes or objectives, and that since he
must budget his time, it was difficult to decide how it might best be disposed;
accordingly, he wished to be associated with ventures which were more likely to
implement his ideas successfully.
